												Well, I finally beat this game after many, many tries and I can definitively say that it's... NOT good.Where do I even start. There are some really major issues with the game that hold it back from being actually worth your time, and I'll try to list a few.HUNGER: Perhaps the biggest problem with this game, that also ties in to many other problems, is the hunger system. It's so poorly balanced. You're either going to be drowning in the over-abundance of food, or you're going to be unlucky and just starve without being able to do anything. The hunger system makes at least 3 classes not viable on anything above easy. To me it seems like it exists solely to pad out the crafting system and to add more difficulty to the inventory management.BULLET SPONGE ENEMIES: No, I'm not talking about dangerous enemies who are hard to bring down. I'm talking about pointless time wasting enemies like Large Protean or the Ape-type enemies: they're awful game design. They deal trivial damage and force you to waste a large amount of turns bringing them down. The before mentioned Large Protean is the guiltiest of all the enemies: it damages your items in your inventory, but you can work around that by just dropping everything and smacking him with melee. Which takes forever. But you have to do it if you want to conserve your ammo/psi, which is essential for victory.NATURAL ABILITY LEVELING: Another time-wasting aspect is the fact that all skills can be leveled to 45 without putting points in. And so you are forced do useless tasks like unlocking doors you don't want to, or missing an enemy 20 times to skill up a particular skill before actually putting points in to it, unless you want to be horribly inefficient. Which you can't be, because this game punishes you HARSHLY for that.THE ENTIRE CRAFTING SYSTEM: It's just bad. Too many components, VERY few useful recipes, and you have to find/unlock new recipes. Have fun browsing the wiki for the list of recipes every time you want to craft something.RNG: Honestly this is about the most random roguelike I've ever played. Even skilling up is random: you get +1-3 points in a skill when you skill it up. There are far too many crafting items that clog the drop tables. There are some very powerful and interesting items in the game, but you will rarely see them thanks to the all the useless junk that will be dropping out of the containers. I swear, there are some items that I've seen ONCE even after playing +200 hours.

ry 12, 2014
												Sword of the Stars: The Pit is a harsh roguelike. Is it a good roguelike? Well, that's where opinions differ. It seems to be missing that key roguelike experience that the community values. But what is it? It has hunger, a scarsity based ammo system, spell trees, randomized numbers and chances, and different classes. What's missing?Fun. That's the statement of this review. SotS: The Pit is missing fun. Roguelikes have always been a unique genre in which its fun to win OR lose. And losing in The Pit is not in the least fun. You either have enough ammo, or you don't. You have food to explore, or you don't. That computers skill roll works, or it doesn't.    There's no "mushroom" in this game of rock, paper, scissors. No surprise element to keep the early game from feeling like a grind; no hilarity to make bad runs enjoyable or memorable.The Pit ends up being too binary. New roguelike players might not understand this, but The Pit definitely suffers from the poor design choice of bad or good. No middle. There's no crazy builds, no adaptation. You place your stats in nearly the same things, find your first weapon, and go from there. Experimentation is reserved for easy mode or not at all.If you enjoy challenges, you'll enjoy this game. If you enjoy games, you won't enjoy SotS: The Pit. Even if you are the first of the two, you may find your frustration venting out at the developers for clearly not knowing how to balance roguelikes.

er 27, 2013
												I spotted Sword of the Stars: The Pit listed as a flash sale on Steam for 75% off of the normal price of $9.99 for a low down price of $2.49. Curse you Valve and your ridiculous summer sales! You managed to suck quite a few bucks out of my debit card on games I may or may not ever get around to and Sword of the Stars seemed to be one of them. Intrigued on trying a top down turn based RPG rogue game this time I decided to try out The Pit and see what is up.The plot of The Pit, as simple as it is, is pretty straightforward. The Zombie Apocalypse or something close to it is occurring on some remote planet and some magical mcguffin that could end it all might be in some place referred to as unoriginality as… The Pit. So you start up a game as a Marine, Engineer, or Scout (actually a pilot, but we called her the scout class anyway!). Ready. Set. Procedurally generated dungeon crawl!And off I went with a Marine, hacking and shooting my way through a seemingly unending supply of rodents and bats. Then a few robots, a couple aliens, all the while watching my health and food bars slowly drain away. And then refill them up with heal kits or rations I brought along then watch them drain away again. Then fill up health from leveling up then watch it drain away again. And then finally, I died. It wasn’t some great last stand or some frightful fleeing for my life, just eventually ran out of health and died. Ho Hum.And then I went again with an engineer. There’s lots of… things scattered randomly around in the rooms and they can be opened with different skills. The engineer is the best at this but he is horribly outgunned and unless you get lucky with one of these loot drops eventually he’s going to die soon to. And then I tried the scout expecting a more sneaky fast person who can run past everything. Nope. The scout is just like the Marine except she’s better at using crappier weapons. *sigh* Speaking of weapons the promo page on Steam boats of “Over 50 weapons and armors with a variety of special effects including flamethrowers, rocket launchers, plasma cannons and powered Brawler armor!” but all I found in my play-throughs were a dinky sword, a piece of ‘stealth’ armor, and a rifle. Meh. I’m sure there’s better stuff way deep down but I never made it and started getting bored quickly.And I started to try to figure exactly why this game is so hum drum boring. At first glance there appears to be some very some good ideas. A complex and important skill system. Lots of loot, a variety of different looking enemies, a randomly generated experience each time you go. But each level looks depressingly bland, the enemies all act boringly stupid, and I was yet to find any awesome loot to scratch at that progressing itch. Outside of having slightly higher chance of succeeding at unlocking things and getting a free heal, leveling up feels downright pointless. I didn’t feel exceptionally stronger at level 5 as I did at level 1. Worse is I felt an incessant need to scour each level and attempt to open every box, fix every console, and unlock every door in hopes of collecting every precious drop of exp I could get my hands on. All in a false hope it would make me strong enough to press on but instead it just wasted my time. There even appears to be a complicated intricate crafting system but I could only scratch the surface of it while trying in vain to get deeper into THE PIT.After seeing a rogue-like game done so well, The Pit feels uninspired. Each time you go into a level you pretty much stand in one spot fighting enemies, waiting for them all to rush at you one at a time. Walk around the level clearing up what’s left and then go deeper. If you are unlucky you’ll run into a high level mob earlier than you should and get crippled. Or worse, you’ll run into a trap and want to rage quit. I wouldn’t exactly call the game unforgivingly difficult, more of just cheaply difficult. Open up a door and stand face to face with a giant machine gun toting mech that fills you with bullets, or worse, the only way to progress is to pass through a door trap. Unlike floor traps which you have a chance of detecting and deactivating, I found no way to deactivate door traps. The most sadistic of all destroys a random item from your inventory. And if it decides to destroy one of your weapons or your ammo, well you might as well just quit now and start anew.In stills the graphics look decent for the sprite style often common of indie games but in action it feels incredibly blocky. It feels exactly like what it is, token pieces moving around a large square grid system. And for turn based combat it is an incredibly uninspired repetition of: point, click, kill. Target an enemy, shoot ‘em with a gun or hack at them with a melee weapon. Or after you’ve gotten really deep and your melee weapon was destroyed and you’re out of ammo, hit them with your fists until they kill you. I especially hate the limitations placed on combat with only 2 moves and performing a combat action ends your turn. The game could have really taken a page from other turn based RPGs with a more intricate action point system that actually felt like I was doing more than just standing in one place and clicking. There also are no stances, cover to hide behind, you cannot move after attacking, jump, sprint, anything. The light scout has no real speed bonus nor does the heavy marine have any speed penalty. Its just simple and dull and really needs a lot of work.In the end, even though the game cost me less than what I’d spend for lunch, I wouldn’t recommend it. There is a lot of potential here for a nice intricate game but the combat system is just so bloody boring and uninspired.Final Score:Graphics: 4/10Game Play: 2/10Music / Ambiance: 3/10Story: 4/10Value: 8/10Overall: 4.2/10Read more indy game reviews on my blog!http://markofithian.com

												The Pit, like most rogue-likes, is all about navigating a vast, deep dungeon while gathering equipment, learning skills and killing monsters. As you progress through The Pit, you will increase your skills such as lock-picking, computers, mechanical, and more. You can use these skills to open doors, hack computers, and repair broken machines, and each successful attempt to do so will increase your associated skill. If you can imagine fallout, remade as a rouge-like, it would be similar to what The Pit offers.A great feature of The Pit is the vast number of items and weapons included within the game. The Pit's weapon selection spans across a number of class types such as melee weapons, pistols, rifles, assault weapons, grenades, and more. Ammo is actually quite limited, this really makes you think about weapon selection as you battle your way though the game. Weapons will also break after continued usage, but items can be found to repair your damaged weapons. Besides its arsenal, The Pit includes items to help increase your abilities, and armour to equip to protect yourself.I found the games controls to be a bit more hassling then they should be. By no means are they bad, but a better control interface would have been appreciated. For example, it would of been nice to be able to control more actions with the mouse or via on-screen buttons. It gets annoying having to continuously hammer the g key to pick up loot from fallen monsters, instead of having the ability to right click on the ground to simply pick them up.I purchased the game during a steam 50% off sale for five bucks, which is a great price for this game. To justify The Pit's ten dollar regular price, I would have expected better graphics and features out of the game. If you are a real keener, feel free to jump in for full price, otherwise, wait for a sale on this one.For more info check out my full review here: http://hashron.com/display.php?id=16

												I'm not a big fan of roguelikes, but the SciFi scenario and the graphic style is right up my alley, so I gave it a try and SotS didn't disappoint.The story is pretty generic, but I guess also not that important in these kind of games. Here it goes: Plague starts on some planet, dude/chick (you) goes to mysterious alien mountain base full of dangers in hope to find a cure. Messages can be found at terminals which contain some more lore, story elements and crafting recipes, but only if your character can decipher them.You can pick between 3 classes (Marine, Engineer, Scout) that come with different stats and equipment and play reasonably different. More classes are added in DLC (up to 10 in total). So what do you do exactly? Well, you fight your way through many (30 I think) randomly generated floors full of increasingly difficult enemies, while trying to find better equipment and prevent starvation. To help you with that, the game comes with a wide variety of guns, armor and tools as well as recipes for food and more guns/armor. In order to get those you must pick locks on containers, hack terminals and, when you're desperate, rummage through recycling bins. To increase your odds of successfully fishing a piece of yummy bacon out of a rotting garbage pile or hitting an enemy, you gain XP and spend points on several skills like "Foraging" and "Assault Rifles". Combat is (semi-)turn-based: If no enemy is near you can move freely but once spotted, it goes turn-based and you can only move a few tiles or attack each turn. SotS is not a short game - Although it's perfectly fine to play for 30 minutes and clear 1-2 floors every now and then, getting to the bottom floor of the alien base will suck a lot of time out of your life, even more so on higher difficulty settings when you dying will become a regular event. The difficulty curve is quite steep - on my first easy playthrough I pretty much breezed through the levels, but now I'm already struggling to make it past the 10th floor on normal. There are many different enemies with different abilities and strengths and an important part of survival is knowing how to counter them (and keeping cures ready for all the negative status effects they can inflict). Soundtrack and effects aren't that good, but like the story it's not something I care too much about in these games. I don't see anything wrong with the controls - simple but effective. The only thing that keeps bugging me is the limited inventory space. With all the guns, food, ammo, crafting materials, etc. your inventory is constantly full. But I guess the hard decision between keeping a potentially life-saving food item or an equally important Medkit is part of the fun.I enjoyed it a lot and will keep playing. It's fun to tune in for 30 minutes to clear some floors and find loot. If you played a lot of roguelikes, SotS might not offer you anything you haven't seen before, but it's still a very solid game. If you're new to the genre, it's a good albeit difficult start.About the DLC - As mentioned before they add new classes but also new equipment (+recipes), enemies, messages, status effects, etc. Mindgames is the biggest one, adding all that plus new skills (Psionics), extra floors and new rooms. More than what you would expect for DLC and worth getting. Gold Edition DLC has less content (mostly equipment and new classes) but is also cheaper. Nice addition, though not a must-have. Can't say anything about The Pilgrim DLC since I don't own that one.

												I would like to start off that the Pit is a great roguelike, however, it is not without it's flaws, which I will try to clarify. When The Pit was first introduced, I saw it as an amazing Roguelike that was not afraid to kill you, because no good Roguelike game should make things easy. However, after spending time with it, and after a few updates which I feel are a hindrance rather than an improvement, I have trouble recommending this game.The biggest problem I feel is the introduction of a storage system. This feature allows you to store both Exp and Items every 5 levels of the pit, allowing other characters to inheret these benefits. This is a large problem, because, in order to have a good "attempt" at the harder difficulties, it is far more beneficial for you to GRIND sacrificial characters to boost up your "real" attempt.Turning a Roguelike into a grind is a terrible idea. However, if you feel that you can ignore that the storage system even exists, you will find a very challenging and rewarding Roguelike system. Be prepared for a VERY long journey however, this is far from a casual experience. A trek through the pit can take a few days even if you have a lot of time to set aside for it, and when your character dies after spending 20+ hours with them, it can be very demoralizing. This was improved somewhat by the ability to "speed up" the game by skipping floors, however in higher difficulties it can be incredibly difficult to survive when you have not had the opportunity to scavenge what you need.If a long difficult journey with lots of stat points, flavor, sci fi, and a beautiful art design with lots of items appeals to you, by all means pick up this game.It is a great game despite it's flaws.

												Do I recommend this game? "Kind of". For once, I will aim to give an extremely brief review.Roguelike games are a dying genre - as in, actual roguelikes, games that follow the genre of the original title for which the genre is named. One can make a powerful argument that so-called "Roguelite" genre - games that incorporate the 'permadeath' aspect, and often have some kind of progression system between multiple runs/tries at the game - are the successor to Roguelike games, and they are numerous with countless quality entries on Steam alone, from Binding of Isaac, to Risk of Rain, to Sunless Sea. Games that may not share typical 'genre' mechanics - they can have elements of platformers, action-RPGs, exploration titles, side-scrolling shooters, first person shooters - but all share that same 'you'll die, but you'll get better' overarching progression path, or unlock path (and, possibly to play into the permadeath aspect, most have a rather dark tone).But actual Roguelikes? Turn-based, resource-management driven games? Very rare, and this is one of the few titles that fits the genre to a T. Huge amount of content, high production quality, and obscenely difficult. If there's a weakness to the game, is that your only hope of success is to 'exploit' non-intuitive mechanics, like not entering your stats screen for a time in order to 'stock' level-ups like a resource, or unequipping armor in the early levels to avoid damaging it, or unequipping weapons and punching doors and other objects for stat points. However, even un-intuitive mechanics still are balanced in some way - the cost making itself known in food, health, psi, anything.This game is a niche title by every definition, but if someone was already into roguelikes, I'd encourage it highly. If someone wanted to TRY a roguelike, I'd honestly recommend the Pokemon Mystery Dungeon games (at least the first two generations), which are very high quality games but, obviously, aimed at a younger and lower-skilled audience, and THEN this.If you're 'on the fence', don't get this game. Nobody can deny that it is a frustrating experience.

												Foreword of advice: I suggest you search for videos on YouTube for a better idea on what the game is like, because, as always, a textual review accounts for very little and does not give a proper impression of what this (or any game, for that matter) is like. There is a demo available, you should probably check it out if you are interested in this game. Also, for a more intricate look into skills/stats/characters, feel free to visit a community wikia at http://sword-of-the-stars-the-pit.wikia.com/wiki/Main_ContentTD;DR #1: My opinion of this game - Amazing, even if with a few pretty major problems;TL;DR #2: Short summary of impressions (Good points, Debatable poins, Negative points):Good points:+ Randomly generated - alot of replayability and variety in your gameplay, each game will be different; You will get your money's worth, if you like these sort of games;+ Many character classes (as of Gold Edition - 8 + 1 secret character) - different strengths/weaknesses which must be accounted for;+ Simple and functional graphics - this will run on a potato;+ (personal) Gameplay - I enjoy these types of games and this is one of the few games that really nails it, think NetHack and you will probably understand what kind of game this is, minus the item interaction hilarity that NetHack had;+ Bloody hard as nails;Debatable points (these are as subjective as they can be):+/- Relatively simplistic gameplay - I like the simplicity, but there's really not alot of nuance to it. Although many advocate that your skill (decision making) is more important, I do not believe it is so, as not finding any equipment by about mid-game is NOT salvagable by your skill;+/- Randomly generated levels can dictate how easy/hard your game is going to be;+/- Some characters are easier to play with - Some characters start out with psionic powers (Psion(Mindgames)/Seeker(Gold Edition)). This allows them to be less dependant on luck and more dependant on skill due to having all the tools necessary (Psionic powers in this case), which allows them to be less dependant on equipment for starting levels;Negative points:- Each run will require alot of time to play - clearing even 10 floors can easily take about 2 hours for me (as I have a tendency of trying to clear the whole floor) and as you go deeper, each  level requires more time, due to stronger enemies, unless you are fortunate with your gear;- This game features unlockable recipes (crafting), which you get from Consoles. Unlocking all recipes (or some potent ones) will require alot of time "grinding". This game does not require crafting to win, but some recipes are nearly essential for survival (Aggressive Antibiotics, for example. Without this, you are very often going to die on your run);- Bloody hard as nails, damn it!A short review of the content:Sword of the Stars: The Pit is a roguelike game, where the levels are randomly generated (rooms/loot/enemies), but to some extent (i.e. you will see harder enemies/better loot the deeper you go). There are multiple characters which you can play as. During the game, you gain levels for your character upon gaining enough experience points. Each character starts with different strengths/weaknesses and different statistic and skill point gains. There are 5 difficulty settings, with the most notable is 'Easy', because it is not, and also, you can only unlock first 50 messages (Messages #1-50), which do contain very good recipes, but will limit the recipe unlockability. Anything above 'Easy' will allow un unlock all messages.At the most basic level, the combat is very simplistic, all you can really do is choose your weapon (good luck with having any!), aim at a target and shoot, hoping the dice rolls go in your favor, although Psionic Powers (Mindgames and Gold Edition only) add additional threats (now there are monsters that use psionic powers) and elements in combat (you can use psionic powers as well).The resources are extremely scarce at the beginning (because you don't find weapon lockers too often on early levels). And the deeper you go, the more you have to try to avoid combat, since enemies get alot stronger and there is more of them. This game can be really harsh on the dice rolls and on more than one occasion, I actually didn't believe the silliness of the dice rolls I got. Also, items (armour/weapons) have durability, which can decrease on successful use, depending on your skill.This game features crafting. Now, this is one of the biggest problems I have with the game - to create something, you require a recipe telling you what you need to create this something (you do not need to unlock the recipe to craft items, but, for the purpose of the exercise, I assume we do not use external resources to find out the recipes before we unlock them). Unlocking those recipes requires alot of time, as out of all the messages (I believe it it about 250+), less than half contain some recipe.The process of unlocking is: finding a console (may requires repair - chance to fail), downloading a message (chance to fail) and decoding a message (you have a percentage chance to decode each word, rather than the whole message, which causes you needing to get the same message multiple times to get the recipe - although sometimes you can figure out the recipe from reading unfinished messages. After crafting something, you will be able to see the recipe, regardless of whether or not you had it decoded fully). Some recipes are damn near essential for living - examples of such are Aggressive Antibiotics (must have, unfortunately) and Hero Sotswitch (less must have, but still a must have).The "grinding" of recipes, along with the general time it takes to play out a single run (I often clock at about 3-4 hours for about a 16 level run due to my tendency of clearing the whole floor) means that it will take a long time before you unlock all the recipes. And the best character to unlock these recipes (Engineer) is extremely poor in combat, which means you will die alot more often.In conclusion, this game is amazing, even if it does have a few flaws (I am sure only a few of what other people may have found). It has amazing replayability, simple combat (which is a flaw to some degree, but I really like it), although somewhat alleviated by psionic powers (but not all characters can get them, realistically speaking). The variety of characters is beneficial to the gameplay, there are also alot of items/weapons/armour. Also, Kerberos (the developer) are a really great company, they released 2 DLC, which are actually expansions, because each adds alot of content (Mindgames - not only new items/enemies/whatnot, but an entirely new gameplay element - Psionic powers; Gold Edition - no new gameplay elements added, but, in my opinion, still totally worth it; a lot of content was added - new classes/items/etc).This game will eat your time, which is both a blessing and a curse.....and trust me - there will be alot of cursing involved. Good luck!P.S. The Casual genre tag is an absolutely ludicrous claim, this game will kick you in the groin and laugh in your face, while savoring your tears of frustration. I guarantee you, you WILL rage at some point during the game, because this game is bloody hard as nails.

												Do you like Rogue-like game? Do you like building and modifying items? Do you like solving puzzles to learn new recipes? If yes, then Sword of the Stars: The Pit is for you!While I can't really understand the "Sword of the Stars" tie-in for this game, this is a great rogue-like game set in space. There are three classes to choose from, each with their own stengths and weaknesses. You have to use your character to explore the abandoned space station. While exploring you will run across monsters, defensive robots, aliens, and traps. Plus you'll find lots of loot and items that you can combine in workbenches or kitchens to make new items, or food, ro help you on your way.Items become damaged through use and battle, and charges run out of electronic devices, but you can repair these and recharge these provided you find the appropriate tools and stations.Death is permanent, and the maps are always random, so the game has high replay value. This is a very fun game and I reccomend that anyone who enjoys a good "light" RPG or Rogue style games to take a look at this.

												A laptop-friendly strategic roguelike. This game is pretty complicated despite looking so simple and is insanely frustrating the deeper into the levels you get. The variety of foes you face keeps you constantly judging your current tactics and there are a multitude of risks and little things you can do to min/max your character. Given recent updates, there are even more characters and options on how you want to clear your way down the depths of this hellish dungeon.I'd say it's a pretty good game, but I find it hard to agitate myself into getting back to it. It's not exactly a game like Binding of Isaac you can pick up for ten minutes and do a whole run (or most of a whole run), be satisfied and put it down for something else. You have to sink a lot of time into each run to really get it anywhere, but at least it lets you save your progress, unlike other roguelikes.3 out of 5 trapped doors.

												Sword of the Stars: The Pit is a great roguelike title with plenty of depth and only some minor drawbacks. The Pit features so much randomization and replay value that it becomes quite addictive to continue playing once you're say... 15 minutes through a game. Being a roguelike, there is of course permanent death in this game. You die and it's all over, your score is added to a high-scores board and then you have to start all over again with one of three playable characters. But chances are you won't really care all that much, as beginning a new game doesn't really feel as daunting as you would imagine it to be. This video game is also a very user-friendly title for anyone that may be new to the roguelike genre. If you have ever played and enjoyed Dungeons of Dredmor and fancy a change of setting, consider this to be the sci-fi DoD.

												SotS: The Pit is my favorite modern Roguelike, in that it gives you the same hopes of Nethack with the RNG as merciless as Jubilex wielding a dead cockatrice.  Instead of random ?s and !s you get random equipment mods and doorway traps.  Ammunition remaining becomes as critical as the # of charges your Roguelike wands had.  An addicting mix of crafting and exploring and good 'ole fashioned turn-based combat.  The gold edition adds a lot (especially classes / loot), but isn't required for A+++ fun.
